sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: In this tutorial, you’ll learn how functions, modules, and classes work in Python. These concepts help you organize your code, avoid repetition, and build reusable programs. To make things easier and more fun, we’ll use simple animal examples.

sections.title: What Are Functions?
sections.content: A function is a reusable block of code that performs a specific task. Functions help keep your programs clean and prevent you from writing the same code repeatedly.

sections.title: What Are Modules?
sections.content: A module is a file that contains Python code, such as functions or variables. Modules help you organize your code and reuse it across different programs.

sections.title: Creating a Module
sections.content: You can place related functions in a separate file and treat it as a module:

sections.title: Using a Module
sections.content: Once a module is created, you can import it and use its functions in another Python file:
sections.code:
# main.py
import animal_sounds

animal_sounds.make_sound('dog')
animal_sounds.make_sound('cat')
animal_sounds.make_sound('cow')
animal_sounds.make_sound('lion')

sections.title: What Are Classes?
sections.content: A class is a blueprint for creating objects. Classes allow you to bundle data (attributes) and behavior (methods) together into a single structure.

sections.title: Summary and Next Steps
sections.content: Functions help you reuse logic, modules help you organize code, and classes help you model real-world objects. These three concepts form the backbone of clean, scalable Python programs. Next, try combining them to build small projects of your own.
